summary: This is an email chain from March 29, 2021, between defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell and an Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York. The emails discuss technical and logistical issues regarding the production of discovery materials in Maxwell's case, including problems with file formats, metadata, missing attachments, and the delivery of evidence to the defendant in prison.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, raising discovery issues with the prosecution regarding file formats, metadata, and delivery of evidence to Maxwell in prison.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Copied on the email chain regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Copied on the email chain regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: Copied on the email chain regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the case. The emails discuss logistical challenges in delivering discovery materials to her while she is incarcerated at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC).

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge who could be asked to issue an order directing the MDC to accept a hard drive containing discovery from the defense.

persons.name: Will
persons.context: A paralegal or contractor for the US Attorney's Office (SDNY) asked to send out discovery materials and confirm their delivery.

connections.description: Everdell is identified as an attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with the prosecution about discovery issues on her behalf.
Both are defense attorneys copied on the same email chain discussing discovery issues for their client, Ghislaine Maxwell.

The AUSA is corresponding with Maxwell's defense team regarding the production of discovery evidence against her.

events.title: Discovery Production
events.description: A production of discovery materials was made by the prosecution to the defense. The email discusses a potential gap in Bates numbers from this production.

events.title: Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: The prosecution references images seized during the 2019 searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences, which were part of the discovery production.

keyFacts: Defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell raised significant technical issues with the discovery produced by the government, including over 109,000 emails missing attachments and over 110,000 electronic files with questionable metadata dates.

The prosecution confirmed that images seized during the 2019 searches of Epstein's residences were included in discovery and did not originate from devices processed by CART (Computer Analysis and Response Team), explaining the lack of CART numbers.

There were logistical challenges in delivering discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell in prison, as the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) would not accept a hard drive from the defense, potentially requiring a court order from Judge Nathan.
The prosecution acknowledged that for files recovered from Epstein's devices that were 'carved or deleted,' no original metadata was recovered and is not viewable.
